newsitem.title: USA: Sybase CEO says accomplished Q3 goals. [CORRECTED 22:58 GMT]
newsitem.headline: Sybase CEO says accomplished Q3 goals. [CORRECTED 22:58 GMT]

text.p: Mitchell Kertzman, one quarter into the job as Sybase chief executive officer, said he accomplished the goals management set at the quarter's outset - to reduce expenses and produce an operating profit.
Sybase eked out an operating profit of $0.01 a share, or $6 million, up from $1 million in the year ago quarter.
That beat Wall Street's mean estimate of a loss of $0.06 a share as tallied by First Call.
(Corrects that company beat, rather than fell short of, mean estimate and changes that estimate from profit to loss).
But Kertzman, who took over as CEO on July 16, said now plans are in place to grow sales and with them, he is "hopeful" that profits will grow over the next few quarters.

"In this era of proposition 211, I'm reluctant to project we'll be profitable. But I am hopeful that over the next several quarters, we will make improvements in results, particularly profits," Kertzman said in an interview.

Proposition 211 is the California ballot initiative that would make corporate officers and board members personally liable for statements that shareholders construe as projections or reasons to invest in a company.
Kertzman said the third quarter profit was largely derived from cutting expenses by $23.8 million and a restructuring.
Future profit growth will need to come from sales, he said.
